thread.title: Westminster, Lovett, HIES, Pace enter postseason
thread.title_full: Westminster, Lovett, HIES, Pace enter postseason

author: E. Marcel Pourtout mpourtout@neighbornewspapers.com (noreply@roswellneighbor.com)
title: Westminster, Lovett, HIES, Pace enter postseason
text: Westminster, Lovett, HIES, Pace enter postseason by E. Marcel Pourtout October 21, 2015 01:59 PM | 261 views | 0 | | Special Photo The Westminster volleyball team won the Area 2AAA tournament championship at Blessed Trinity in Roswell on Oct. 8. Front row, from left, assistant coach Catherine Zidow, Elizabeth Harvey, Virginia Thom, Addie Croft, Hannah Morgan and Caroline Welsh. Middle row, from left, assistant coach Colin Mackey, Gabi Dolan, Lexi Saulny, Ansley McNeel, Claire Corbin and Margaret Moran. Back row, from left, Maggie McSwain, Liz Bailey, Maya Longacre, Kayla Chambers, Mary Tucker and head coach Jona Braden. slideshow The Georgia High School Association (GHSA) volleyball state playoffs have begun with several local programs embarking on their journey for a state championship.In Class 3A, Westminster has started the postseason as the top seed out of Area 2AAA after defeating defending state champion Blessed Trinity on the road in the area tournament championship on Oct. 8. Senior Caroline Welsh had a team-high nine kills for the Wildcats while sophomore Gabi Dolan earned eight kills in the win. Junior Maya Longacre had 32 assists.“We withstood together from one point to the next as we battled to the end,” Westminster coach Jona Braden said. “We’re excited and focused on the next leg of our voyage. Each day we embrace the work that is ahead and are humbled and grateful for the opportunity to increase our capacity-to-do inside and out.” Welsh was named the area’s player of the year while Elizabeth Harvey and Hannah Morgan were selected to the All-Area team.Westminster opened the state playoffs hosting Ringgold in the first round on Oct. 14. The Wildcats won the match 3-0 behind a game-high 13 kills from Dolan and Lexi Saulny’s six aces.Wesminster returns to action this week when it hosts Haralson County in the second round of the playoffs. The Rebels won their first-round match against Tooms County 3-1 and have won nine contests this season.The Class 2A playoffs will have three programs representing the local area starting this week. Defending state champion Holy Innocents’ finished first in Area 4AA this season, earning a top seed in the postseason. The Golden Bears, who have won 29 matches this year, open the playoffs at home against Bremen.“We’re very excited about the postseason,” Holy Innocents’ coach Taylor Noland said. “We have to hold ourselves accountable and continue to stay focused and work hard. I know our team is motivated to continue in the playoffs. Either we perform or the season is over.”Pace Academy placed first in Area 3AA while also earning a top seed. The Knights own 21 match wins so far this season and host 20-match winner Rabun County in the first round of the postseason.“We’re very excited winning an area for the first time,” Pace Academy coach Anna Bush said. “We’re confident in our abilities but not over confident. We won’t take Rabun County lightly.”Lovett has won 10 matches this season and finished second in Area 3AA. The Lions open the postseason against Darlington, which has won 24 matches this year.Mount Vernon Presbyterian concluded its season with a 3-0 defeat to Paideia on Oct. 15. The Mustangs won 20 matches this year.
